late Oscar dePaz, father, grandfather, great grandfather, and poet patriarch,
unwavering patriot, ‘poet laureate’ of Jayuya, Puerto Rico, bohemian, baseball
lover and, as remembered by his grandchildren, master maker of bistec and habichuellas.
Romantic, a dreamer of beauty. 
To honor his memory and in gratitude for
Oscar’s inspiration to two generations of artists, musicians and poets, his son
Gilberto de Paz has put to music a choice selection of his best poems in a
beautifully arranged CD, a just and proper tribute to the patriarch of our
family artistic tradition. 
The CD will be presented in April 2015 in an
event at the historic Thomas Center in Gainesville, Florida. For that occasion,
we want to publish a small poem book that will bring together a select sample
of his poems, including the ones selected for the CD, for participants in this
presentation, which we expect to be a beautiful evening of music, poetry and
art - a modest endeavor to honor a man that infused a modest life with an epic
zest and modeled the poet and artist to his grateful children and
grandchildren. Books that are not distributed the night of the event, will be
available in local independent bookstores.
Risks and challenges
The CD
is recorded and published. The book is laid out. We just need your help to take
it to the printer. We are only waiting for your support!
Para honrar el recuerdo y
el legado de inspiración del poeta jayuyano Oscar de Paz, su hijo Gilberto de
Paz ha musicalizado una selección de su poesía en un CD con arreglos de Amaury Lopez
Jackson.
El CD se presentará en
Abril 2015 en un evento histórico en el Thomas Center de Gainesville, Florida.
Para acompañar la presentación del CD y ayudar a dar a conocer su poesía,
queremos juntar en un modesto poemario una muestra selecta de lo mejor de su
poesía, incluyendo los poemas seleccionados para el CD, para completar lo que
esperamos será una bella noche de música, poesía y arte.  Los poemarios que no se distribuyan la noche
de la presentación se distribuirán localmente en librerías independientes. Una
modesta propuesta en honor de quien vivió y modeló para sus agradecidos hijos y
nietos el alma del poeta y el artista.
Un donativo a cualquier nivel
será enormemente agradecido, pero también ofrecemos premios a varios niveles
para aquellos de ustedes que quieran acompañarnos más generosamente en esta
jornada.

story:
Surprising. Funny. Opinionated. Vivid. RiDE Magazine

So here it is, Different Natures, the third book, 3 trips over a 12 year period from drug-induced recklessness to experienced solitude. It covers 24,000 miles across the continent of North America from the Alaskan Arctic Circle to below the Tropic of Cancer in Mexico.  The book explores the various natures of both a reluctant maturity and the extreme environments between destinations.

Three very different journeys on three different bikes but all with a common thread. Once again written in diary format, as that has been a popular trait of the last two books.

It’s been a long and challenging production process but the book is ready for print-362 pages, 8 of them with colour photos. This is where you come in. If you would be so kind as to pre-order this, I promise you, before the spring is over, you will receive a signed copy of Different Natures. You will discover where this insatiable lust for travel came from, where I went with it, and you have the power to dictate where the publication of this book will take me. This campaign ends on Easter Monday, the book will take about 2 weeks to print and then it will be sent to you. 

Thinking back to the launch of my first book In Search of Greener Grass, three short, no wait, three long, actually three normal-length years ago. No one knew who the hell Graham Field was, and there was no reason why they should have.

 I feel dream-come-true elation when I'm actually asked when this, my third book, will be available.

 I'll try to explain why. You go off on a motorbike a ride to Mongolia, you write about it, spend your savings having a book published and all your spare time promoting it. Then not only do people buy it on utter trust, investing their hard-earned money in your ramblings but then they actually say they liked it... and then buy the next one. All I ever wanted was to be a writer and with the help of others, I’ve become just that.

  Some people prefer In Search of Greener Grass to Ureka and vice versa, it’s a relief to me that neither one stands out as better. Just different appeal depending on the reader's preferences. It reassured me I was not just a 'one book wonder'. Now a third work about to enter the equation. As with the last 2 I have no idea how it will be judged, only proof readers and copy editors have seen it and they won't tell you it's rubbish because they want to be paid. Well actually, one person has seen it, and he’s quite significant. A 107,000 word document was read and reviewed by the editor of RiDE magazine, (a publication of utter credibility) and he was under no obligation to be nice to me, and the review was favourable. Phew!

I am also offering some limited and very reduced price deals on my other books in case you have read the reviews on Amazon  and realise you need these in your life.  

So please share this post and spread the word.  

Thank you for reading.

Graham Field

story:
Summary

Rape and sexual assault are a fact of life. It doesn’t have to be that way. But to change it we have to start young. That’s what The Outbounds is about: awareness and attitudes among younger girls and boys.

We are launching The Outbounds to reach young women and young men. The Outbounds is an ebook embedded with hyperlinks to 35 websites on rape prevention, rape awareness, peer support strategies, rape prevention activism. It’s a romantic, engaging thriller written for the target audience - young adult readers ages 13 to 18.

Sexual abuse and assault are hurting hundreds of thousands of teens and young adults. Teens are growing up in a toxic atmosphere  that surrounds sex.  . .internet exploitation, cyber-bullying, victim blaming, rape and assault on campus and in the community.

To break the cycle, we have to prepare pre-teen girls and boys to anticipate the threat and begin to protect themselves. We can help them challenge attitudes that contribute to the culture of rape. We can help them do something to prevent sexual assault.  

Vibrant exciting fiction draws young readers. It can also expose them to serious and important matters. They read The Outbounds and while they’re reading the book it links them  to things they need to know and think about.

The internet (the site of a lot of sexual shaming and cyber-bullying) can be a part of the solution. Once we have the ebook ready to launch, we’ll use social media for support and buzz and reinforcement of the book’s ideas.

Help us prepare young women and young men to live without rape. Support The Outbounds.


READ AN EXAMPLE OF HOW WE'LL DEVELOP The Outbounds at our website: imagineaworldwithoutrape.org. Our website is the place our readers will go to tell their stories, share their experiences, offer their support. 

Who Are We?

We are a project team with backgrounds  in writing, teaching, publishing, social media and public affairs. We are creating The Outbounds to make a difference in the lives of pre-teens and young women and men.

Oralee Wachter is the project director. She’s an accomplished writer and media producer. Lynne Smilow is team leader. She is an educator and media professional. Thomas Boyd is program manager. He is a  nonprofit and communications veteran. Nhu An Do is social media advisor and coordinator. She’s an internet professional.

This project is about having an impact on young lives. If you can help us with ideas or resources, volunteer to join our team.

What’s our track record? 

We have dealt with these issues before. We were the people to define and address acquaintance rape for what it was. We created the most successful plain-talk book and video about HIV/AIDS. We wrote the book that told kids they didn’t have to keep it a secret when adults molested them. We've managed big national public service campaigns and we've created coalitions to support our work.

What We Need & What You Get
We're well underway with the book itself. We need to raise $15,000 to get the project out to the world. We’ll spend the money to finish the book and incorporate hyperlinks and collaborations with agencies and organizations.
Besides the Indiegogo campaign, we're working through our fiscal sponsor to apply for other funding. We invite partnerships and collaborations from funders who care about this issue.
What happens if we don’t raise the $15,000? We’ll use every dime we raise to push the project as far down the road as we can. This means that we’ll continue writing a treatment. We’ll continue to approach foundations and other possible supporters.

The Impact

When you donate to this campaign you help equip young women (and young men) to think about rape and sexual assault. For too long, rape prevention has waited until campus, waited until the workplace. The Outbounds gets an early start.  Your donation gets us the funding base we will use to write, produce and publish a groundbreaking resource for young people.

Risks & Challenges

This Indiegogo campaign is only one thing we’re doing to make this book happen. We're approaching major donors, we're collaborating with dozens of nonprofits across the country and we're building a vibrant online platform for the project, with links and resources and social media.

Rape and sexual assault are in the papers every day. Now is the tipping point. We have brought this project to Indiegogo because we believe allies are out there and we want to get started right away. Join us, give what you can, and become a part of the critical business of helping young people become informed and aware.

 Other Ways You Can Help

Tell everyone you know about this campaign. Send them the link to the Indiegogo page.

Use the Indiegogo share tools to help you spread the word.

Next time you meet with your friends, coworkers, neighbors, teammates, etc., pass the hat and make a collective contribution to the campaign.

story:
TE INVITAMOS A VER EL SIGUIENTE VIDEO



Cuando Ícaro le pidió a su mejor amigo, el caracol Helix, que lo ayudara a alcanzar el Sol, no tenía idea de todas las aventuras por las que pasarían juntos.

Este libro enseña a los niños el valor de la amistad, el trabajo en equipo, el amor al prójimo y la solidaridad.  Pero sobre todo les enseña a no abandonar sus sueños y a no darse por vencido ante los problemas.  “ICARO, la oruga que quería llegar al Sol” es una maravillosa historia, con personajes entrañables,  que también le gustará a los adultos y los hará reflexionar.

Desde hace varios años han estado naciendo en nuestro planeta niños con características especiales, entre ellas un alto nivel de conciencia y mucha energía creativa y espiritual. Niños que poseen una sabiduría increíble y que vienen a ayudarnos a crear esa Nueva Tierra que todos queremos. 

Nuestra misión es activarles la información con la que nos van a ayudar a crear esa Nueva Tierra de Paz, Amor y Armonía. Queremos darle a esos niños una alternativa de lectura que les ayude en su desarrollo como seres humanos libre de condicionamientos y que le ayude a desarrollar, desde temprana edad, una conciencia de unidad. 

La impresión y distribución de la primera edición del libro infantil “ICARO, la oruga que quería llegar al Sol”. Un cuento cargado de humor, aventura y mucha emotividad.   


Al colaborar con este proyecto vas a poder recibir diferentes recompensas que van desde postales digitales, el libro digital, el libro impreso tapa dura, afiches, borradores originales y mucho más.  Para más detalles puedes ver en la columna derecha de esta página. 


Nada, el libro esta listo para mandarse a imprimir.  Esta completamente diagramado e ilustrado. Contiene 26 páginas y la portada será de tapa dura. 

                       

Definitivamente existen intereses que no desean que nuestros niños aprendan a reflexionar, sólo desean robots programados que sigan haciendo funcionar el sistema. Las grandes editoriales de libros infantiles, las que distribuyen el 90% de los libros que están en las tiendas, no quieren ofrecerle a los niños libros con mensajes.

En nuestras manos está poder darle una alternativa de lectura a estos niños. Ofrecerle libros infantiles que tengan un mensaje que vibre en la misma frecuencia en la que se encuentran ellos. 

Para las ilustraciones de este libro hemos aplicado las mismas técnicas que se utilizan en la industria del cine y la televisión. Primero se crearon los escenarios, luego se ubicaron las luces para la iluminación y por último las cámaras. Para cada situación de la historia se realizó una puesta en escena y luego se seleccionó la mejor toma de cámara. En pocas palabras todo lo que ustedes ven en las ilustraciones del libro, existe en forma virtual.

                   


El monto recaudado se utilizará en la impresión de la primera edición del libro que consta de 1000 ejemplares. Igualmente pagaremos los servicios de distribución y mercadeo a una compañía americana que posee una amplia red de distribución en las diferentes tiendas de Estados Unidos. Si el monto alcanzado lo permite, también publicaremos el libro en inglés. 

El libro se mandará a imprimir aproximadamente el 30 de Enero de 2015.  (Debemos esperar a que Indiegogo nos haga la transferencia). Según nuestros cálculos debemos estar recibiendo la producción completa de esta primera edición a finales del mes de febrero 2015.  Sin embargo estos tiempos pueden variar, todo depende del término acordado por la imprenta al momento de hacer la orden de impresión.

Las recompensas que no incluyan el libro físico se comenzarán a enviar el 21 de enero de 2014. Las recompensas que sí incluyan el libro físico se comenzarán a enviar una vez que hayamos recibido los libros impresos.


ACUERDO PARA VENEZUELA:

Logramos un acuerdo con la compañía directobox.net y el envío del libro físico a Venezuela solo costará $6. 



El 10% de la producción total del libro se donará a bibliotecas públicas para que el mensaje del libro le llegue a la mayor cantidad de niños posible. 


EL AUTOR:
Daniel López de Medrano, nació en Caracas y estudió periodismo en la Universidad Central de Venezuela.  A lo largo de 25 años se ha desempeñado como productor y director de radio y televisión, tanto en Venezuela como en E.E.U.U. 

Sus programas de TV permanecieron por muchos años en la lista de los programas más vistos de la televisión venezolana. En los últimos 10 años, se ha desarrollado como productor de comerciales en el mercado hispano de los Estados Unidos.  

A partir del año 2010 decidió entregarse en cuerpo y alma a escribir libros y dictar conferencias para ayudar a crear una nueva conciencia dentro del público hispano, una conciencia de unidad. 

Daniel López de Medrano ha logrado explicar conceptos de Física Cuántica y espiritualidad de una manera amena y fácil de entender en sus libros “Reflexiones 2012“ y “121 Reflexiones para Despertar la Conciencia y Evolucionar Espiritualmente”. 

En el año 2013 decidió incursionar en un nuevo mercado y escribió su primer libro infantil “ICARO, la oruga que quería llegar al Sol”

EL ILUSTRADOR:
Juan Carlos Santana Llebry, nació en la isla de Gran Canaria, España. Tomó clases de dibujo artístico en la Universidad Miami Dade Communinity College, de la ciudad de Miami. Desde 1997 se ha desempeñado como diseñador grafico y post-productor en la televisión hispana de los Estados Unidos. 

En el año 2009 se graduó en la escuela de animación 3D y efectos visuales ubicada en Universal Studios Orlando.

A partir del año 2010 se une a los proyectos de Daniel López de Medrano sobre nueva conciencia, encargándose de la diagramación, diseño de los libros y la producción del material audiovisual de las conferencias del mencionado autor.

En el año 2013 logra poner en práctica sus conocimientos de producción, diagramación, modelaje y animación 3D, creando las ilustraciones del libro “ICARO, la oruga que quería llegar al Sol”.

En el año 2013 logra poner en práctica sus conocimientos de producción, diagramación, modelaje y animación 3D, creando las ilustraciones del libro “ICARO, la oruga que quería llegar al Sol”.

story:
The mission

Here is the deal. Human trafficking mortifies me. It is something I want to believe doesn't happen. But it does. In the past year I have had a few interesting circumstances happen where this issue has been brought to the forefront of my attention.

Most recently I was given a challenge by a director at IJM (international justice mission) to face my fears and use my skills to create meaningful change in India.

I heard the call. Now it is time to go.

I will be heading to India to help IJM attack this issue head on. While I am there I will be doing things like helping these girls along the journey into housing, education, job readiness, working with social enterprises to attack this from an economic standpoint and researching the problem. I imagine a world where these people are freed. Both the women and perpetrators. This mission is one small step toward that world.


It takes a village

I am asking you, my community, to be a part of this mission. To come along with me on this journey. I will need $3,400 to make it happen. The money will be going towards a plane ticket and a place to stay while I am there.

But I don't believe in getting without giving.

And that is where this gets exciting.

The Perks!

For co-piloting this mission I would like to give you two things I know best:  innovation and storytelling.
I will be writing a short book called "Jugaad Innovation" (see more below) based on research I have been doing for five years and my experience immersed in the world's most surprisingly innovative culture. It will tell a story and give you a step by step guide for making your ideas happen with little to no money.

Here is a quick overview of the perks!
  • Poster with distilled lessons
  • E-book or bound copy of Jugaad Innovation
  • Become a part of the book! - I will use your story as a supporting anecdote!
  • Community Indian dinner and party (I have Chinese on speed dial)
Oh yeah, and if we don't raise $3,400, you get totally refunded and the campaign ends. That would suck. So lets bring this home!

The Impact

I will be partnering with IJM and other organizations in India to combat human trafficking. These partners work relentlessly to bring justice and rescue girls who are trapped in modern day slavery. Some specifics tasks include helping these girls along the journey into housing, education, job readiness, and working with social enterprises to attack this from an economic standpoint. The mission is to help these women make the bold move to sustainable independence. 

The Book

Jugaad Nation tells the story of one of the most surprisingly innovative countries in the world, India. It provides a distilled set of principles and application questions designed to take your ideas from concept, to reality.

For the past five years I have been a student practitioner of innovation, flying around the world helping big companies make their dreams a reality. I have researched countless methods and causes of innovation, and even been invited to speak at TEDx on the topic.

In my research, one of the most widely-applicable philosophies for making ideas happen is the concept of Jugaad. Jugaad is a colloquial hindi word that means an innovative fix or simple work around. It uses severe constraints or obstacles as accelerators for smart solutions.

Your contribution to this mission will pay for my to India. While I am there, I will be doing missions work immersing myself in the culture and taking note of lessons learned doing missions work I will be immersed in the culture and taking note the lessons learned.

In the end I will provide you with a handbook filled with learnings, pictures and your anecdotes that will help bring any idea from concept to reality.

Tell me about IJM

IJM (International Justice Mission) is a global organization that protects the poor from violence in the developing world.
They are a global team of lawers, investigators, social workers, community activists and other professionals at work in 20 communities.
They work in:
  • Strengthening justice systems
  • Brining criminals to justice
  • Rescuing victims
  • Restoring survivors
Learn more here: https://www.ijm.org/

I want to help but I'm broke!

I've been there! What would help is to get the word out and make noise about this campaign. There are a few share tools on this site, but you can also copy and paste the URL into your facebook or email to let the world know!

I want to know more...

Lets talk! Call me at 765-993-0798

story:
I want to be the best journalist that I can possibly be. How does that happen? When experience meets the best learning opportunities. Thread at Yale is my next opportunity and I need YOU to help be a part of MY story. 

A couple weeks ago, although the program was impressed by my application, I was told that I would be on the waiting list until a spot opened up. 

This week - I got the green light to attend!

Thread at Yale is a gathering of exceptional journalists and storytellers. Each day, we'll gather and go over a project we're currently working on.

It's perfect because not only do I want to pick the brains of other successful journalists like Emily Bazelon of the New York Times Magazine, or Catherine Burns of The Moth, or even Glynn Washington who created the public radio show 'Snap Judgment,' but I just want to be in an innovative, organic environment where ideas can flourish.

The program runs June 7-10, 2015 on the Yale University campus. (If you want to read more, check it out here: http://yaledailynews.com/blog/2015/03/27/yale-to-offer-summer-journalism-program/)

Help me get there!

PROJECT:

Your contribution will help with my platform, The M Report, (www.the-m-report.com).

Read more about the content and the contributors who engage in topics that concern the minority community. Together, we'll help my platform grow!

story:
The Brian Mannix Autobiography (Only 1000 copies)
Special Limited Edition: Early Release!



It was always my goal that this book be like a conversation with me. The only person who could write my story properly is me. A ghost writer just wouldn’t sound right and probably wouldn’t swear as much.

The best biographies I’ve read are Elvis Aaron Presley by Alannah Nash and Motley Crue’s The Dirt. The reason I like these two books is because they are detailed and made me feel like I was actually in the room with Elvis when he was plotting to kill Mike Stone and on the Japanese bullet train when Nikki Sixx went crazy. I didn’t want to just list events. I wanted the reader to feel like they are taking acid with the X-Men, acting in Chopper or Dancing With The Stars! I wanted to share the experience.

Along the way I realised that the story of my life was way more important to me than any amount of money a publisher was advancing me. I’m really proud of this book and was not prepared to have my story butchered by a series of publishers who only want to print 300 or so pages with 16 pages of photos. Check it out that’s what 90% of bio books are. This is what happens when money is the bottom line and art is determined by focus groups and committees. It is a shit way to decide how to tell a story!

If you want something done right you have to do it yourself. For that reason I’m crowdfunding the book and telling my story the way it was intended. By pre ordering this book you will allow me to achieve that… and it will make an Uncanny X-Mas present!

I am not asking for charity. I just want to sell you the book publishers would have fucked up. Your money will be used to help design, print and deliver in to your very hands, my uncensored story. It’s a full on process and I can’t do it without your help.

This is a limited edition uncensored early release.
Only 1000 copies will be printed - all signed and numbered. 
It will only be available to purchase during the month of October.  
No orders can be accepted after October 31st.

For an exclusive signed copy of my book, $35 (+postage) is all I require.

Check out the packages available and see what interests you.
Thank you!

story:
The vision...

Our Mirror Book is a picture book that empowers kids with the knowledge that our world is a reflection of the energy we send out into it. Our Mirror Book reminds us that changing things for the better begins by looking at the person in the mirror. It encourages children to think, believe, feel and do positive things in order to see positive reflections.  ...And I'm going to publish it with your help!

You can read most of the book for free at alexwallman.com.
(And to receive a surprise free download item, please sign up to the mailing list!)



Who I am and why I'm making this book...

Hi! I'm Alex Wallman, creator of Our Mirror Book. Throughout my career I've worked on a lot of projects helping people, animals and the environment. I've done things as diverse as driving a ship through Antarctica to protect whales, to making communications about the health risks of drinking too much soda. These projects have been with groups and individuals as diverse as Sea Shepherd, Greenpeace, Yosi Sergeant (formerly of The White House's Office of Public Liaison), The California Endowment, and Richard Branson's Carbon War Room.

Being involved in various forms of activism and art led me to wonder how I could be best put to use in creating positive change. And Our Mirror Book is the result of this thinking. Our Mirror Book aims to help kids help themselves, and inspire them to 'be the change they wish to see in the world'. It shows us that life isn't just something that happens TO us, it's also something that we CREATE with what we choose to think, believe, say & do. It shows the reader that life's good 'reflections' come back to us in greater and greater abundance the more we focus on creating them.

I was inspired to make this book by the books that affected me most as a child. As children our books color our dreams and guide our velocities. With limited life experience as kids, these books have a huge power to shape how we perceive and interact with the world. The realization of just how much the books of my childhood molded me meant that when I had the idea for Our Mirror Book, I knew it was important enough to follow it through to its completion.

What I need & what you'll get...

I'm looking to raise $7500. This will pay for a print run of 1000 copies of Our Mirror Book from a local printer, and will cover shipping to my home for storage and distribution. After delivery I'll post some of the books as rewards to donors, sell them, and give them to kids who can't afford them.  This amount will also cover the creation of any ancillary perks claimed by contributors and the shipping of these items.

Any extra funds I raise beyond my goal will go toward translating the book to Spanish & getting it out to a wider audience. Overshooting my goal will also help build lesson plans that further the ideas contained in the book. (These will be created in conjunction with elementary-curriculum-specialists and are already in the pipeline.)

Speaking of rewards, we have some amazing ones on offer, including:

Signed copies of the book.

Signed Our Mirror Book wall prints.

Original & custom art pieces created by me, including portraits of loved ones.

Printed thank yous in the book.

Dedication of the entire book to you, or someone you love.

An amazing prize pack from Deepak Chopra and The Chopra Foundation.

Signed rarity packs from The Drums and a personal video from Jonny Pierce.

A great fan package from OK-GO.

An original children's song created by Paul McCartney's DJ, Chris Holmes.

Or, if you're game, I'll even show you the studio where I created the book, cook you dinner at my house, and then Devendra Banhart will pop by the house to sing you a song, in person!

Please view the column to the right to see more reward details.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't support this campaign financially, don't worry! You can still help by making some noise! Share it via social media or email! Tell your friends about it, use the IndieGogo share tools you can find on this page, or email alex.author.man@gmail.com and tell me about an organization who you think may be interested in sharing it via their social media!

None of this would be possible without your help, so from the bottom of my heart, THANK YOU!

story:
Jordan Krall here from DUNHAMS MANOR PRESS...
I want to publish this excellent collection of stories that are inspired by Stefan Grabiński.
Money raised will go to the authors and artists involved including Brian Evenson, Steve Rasnic Tem, Damian Murphy, Christian Wiessner, Michael Faun, C.M. Muller, Ron Wier, Michael R. Colangelo, Trevor Kroger, Liam Garriock, William Tea, and more.

And yes, I know that Grabinski wasn't ALL about trains... but personally, that's what really attracted me to his work. My father (who is now on hospice care) worked for NJ Transit for over 40 years and so anything railroad related really hits home for me.

The plan is to start this shipping in January 2019.

Thanks!

and more TBA.

story:
Story of My Book

New Grit: Startups in America's Comeback Cities is a story of optimism and a story of expectation. It looks at the cultural and mechanical traits that seven former industrial powerhouse cities (DET, STL, CIN, CLE, PIT, BUF, BAL) share that give them reason to be optimistic about a comeback built on the shoulders of entrepreneurship. At the same time, it lays out the steps to be taken within these cites to transform optimism into reality.

My name is Andy Gordon and I am the author of New Grit. I wrote this book because I grew up and have lived in comeback cities much of my life and find myself carrying the flag for why they're so great wherever I go. I wrote this book to help others recognize comeback cities' potential to not only regain their own prosperity of decades past, but to help propel prosperity on a regional and national scale.

My hope is that, in reading this book, you will discover a sense of hope for comeback cities and an understanding of the importance of entrepreneurship in achieving this goal. In this book, I hope to instill the same sort of passion and excitement that I have for the resurgence of once-great American cities in you. And then ultimately I want you to see this book as a tool to help you understand what can be done in your own community to grow its entrepreneurial spirit.

In this book, you'll learn about everything from the history of small steel towns to the story of how Silicon Valley came to be. You'll hear how a bunch of cities known for awful sports teams can harness their unrelentingly rabid fandom to boost their economy. You'll hear:

 

  • Why the revival of comeback cities matters beyond each city's own borders
  • What traits make these cities uniquely equipped to ride startups to resurgence
  • How these cities can proceed to make this vision a reality

 

New Grit: Startups in America's Comeback Cities is a non-fiction book that a variety of audiences will be fascinated by. If you are a rust belt enthusiast like myself, you will find optimism for the future of this area. If you are interested in cities, startups, or startup community development, you will find an application of many theories to specific cities given their unique traits and cultures. If you are a millennial who can’t fathom the possibility of owning a home and having a good quality of life in your current city, you will find promise in places you hadn’t considered. And finally, if you are a fan of comebacks and underdogs, or are simply wondering how a community can dig itself out of a hole, look no further.

Like so many of us who have committed to proving to ourselves that we can get up off the mat, these comeback cities are determined to prove their supporters right and their naysayers wrong. They are so immensely confident in the spirit and resources of their city that its resurgence is inevitable. They're not hoping for a comeback, they're waiting.

 

The Book - New Grit: Startups in America's Comeback Cities

The book is written in four parts....
  • Part 1 “Comeback Cities” introduces our cities, covers the reasons why anyone should care about these cities' resurgence and why startups are a key driver, while acknowledging the reasons cities like Kansas City, Columbus, and Nashville didn't quite make the cut.
  • Part 2 “Mechanical Traits: Industry, Institutions, and Expertise” contains examples from each of the comeback cities spanning historic industry expertise to cheaper costs of doing business to the importance of existing Fortune-500 companies in places like Cincinnati.
  • Part 3 “Cultural Traits: Love, Connection, and Realism” looks at the more human side of these cities. Think things like the intense love of place you've been exposed to by any Detroiter, Buffalonian, or Yinzer talking endlessly and lovingly about their hometown. This section also looks at the historic impact of only a few industries and employers on the entrepreneurial fabric of these cities' populations.
  • Finally, Part 4 “Igniting the Comeback” lays out the keys and steps to tapping into the traits shared by come back cities.

 

What I Need & What You'll Get

This book will be published with New Degree Press. I set up the pre-order tiers to help cover the book's publishing costs. Money raised will go towards the following:
  • The editor I will work with to revise and publish my manuscript in December 2019
  • The cover design of my book - the mockups you see currently are a placeholder
  • The layout design for the interior of my book (physical copy and Ebook formats)
  • The copyediting for my book - to help polish things up prior to publication
  • The launch & promotion efforts for my book - when I ultimately publish this winter

When I pre-sell 100 copies of my book, I will publish. When I pre-sell 150 copies of my book, I will also publish an audiobook. When I pre-sell 200 copies of my book, I will publish a hardcover edition.

I am also offering some exclusive rewards for people who pre-order my book now:

  • You will receive a personally signed copy of my book when I publish
  • A personal, handwritten thank you note for pre-ordering my book
  • Your name will appear in a special acknowledgements section of my book
  • Early access to the introduction of my book and my entire manuscript, with the opportunity to review it and give me early feedback
  • The opportunity to help give me feedback and be involved in selecting my cover
  • I will do a book topic/workshop seminar where I will share experience the experiences of writing my book
  • And more...

 

About the Author

Andy Gordon is a Buffalo native working with Techstars to develop the city's entrepreneurial ecosystem, MBA candidate at Georgetown University McDonough School of Business, assistant football coach at Gonzaga College High School in DC, dog dad to purebred mutt and March 2016 pet-of-the-month award winner at his vet Beau Gordon, damaged but persevering Bills and Sabres fan, and renowned fun uncle to nine Gordons.

Andy was inspired to write this book while crying into his beer after a Buffalo Bills 54-24 loss to the San Diego Chargers on the back of Nathan Peterman's five interceptions. He began anticipating the same old jabs his friends would throw at him about the lowly Bills the next day, but heard the same voice in his head that he's heard for his old life. The voice, sounding ever-haggard, insisted that every loss like this Peterman debacle would make any eventual championship all the more meaningful. This seed began to grow in the coming weeks as he dove deeper into the startups and venture capital world while at Georgetown, recognizing the overlap in these two ideas: that places that have experienced such a long string of losses not only have the most to gain in a resurgence, but have the pride and love necessary to fuel that resurgence from within.

For more information you can connect with Andy at azgordon1@gmail.com and LinkedIn.

 

Risks & Challenges

The biggest challenge with publishing a book is delivering the finished book to the backer, specifically my mailing of the book to you. I have eliminated this risk by building into the campaign the mailing and shipping costs of your signed copies to you within each pre-order tier.

The risk of delivering the pre-sale copies of my book is contingent on the publisher we use. I will be working closely with New Degree Press to make sure we get the earliest possible ship date of the signed book copy to you. We will keep all pre-sale backers up-to-date as my book hits each key milestone and publishes. You will know when the copies of my book you pre-ordered are expected to ship.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute by buying a copy, I'd greatly appreciate it if you could:
  • Please share my pre-sale campaign on Facebook, Twitter, and LinkedIn with your friends, family, and network. Please use #NewGrit and tag me as well as my publisher, New Degree Press so we can help amplify your efforts.
  • Please share my pre-sale campaign page via Indiegogo at the top of the page.
  • Please share my book to friends, family members, or co-workers who you think would enjoy it.

 

Thank you so much for all of your love and support!
story_txt:
Story of My Book
New Grit: Startups in America's Comeback Cities is a story of optimism and a story of expectation. It looks at the cultural and mechanical traits that seven former industrial powerhouse cities (DET, STL, CIN, CLE, PIT, BUF, BAL) share that give them reason to be optimistic about a comeback built on the shoulders of entrepreneurship. At the same time, it lays out the steps to be taken within these cites to transform optimism into reality.My name is Andy Gordon and I am the author of New Grit. I wrote this book because I grew up and have lived in comeback cities much of my life and find myself carrying the flag for why they're so great wherever I go. I wrote this book to help others recognize comeback cities' potential to not only regain their own prosperity of decades past, but to help propel prosperity on a regional and national scale.My hope is that, in reading this book, you will discover a sense of hope for comeback cities and an understanding of the importance of entrepreneurship in achieving this goal. In this book, I hope to instill the same sort of passion and excitement that I have for the resurgence of once-great American cities in you. And then ultimately I want you to see this book as a tool to help you understand what can be done in your own community to grow its entrepreneurial spirit.In this book, you'll learn about everything from the history of small steel towns to the story of how Silicon Valley came to be. You'll hear how a bunch of cities known for awful sports teams can harness their unrelentingly rabid fandom to boost their economy. You'll hear:
 

Why the revival of comeback cities matters beyond each city's own borders
What traits make these cities uniquely equipped to ride startups to resurgence
How these cities can proceed to make this vision a reality

 
New Grit: Startups in America's Comeback Cities is a non-fiction book that a variety of audiences will be fascinated by. If you are a rust belt enthusiast like myself, you will find optimism for the future of this area. If you are interested in cities, startups, or startup community development, you will find an application of many theories to specific cities given their unique traits and cultures. If you are a millennial who can’t fathom the possibility of owning a home and having a good quality of life in your current city, you will find promise in places you hadn’t considered. And finally, if you are a fan of comebacks and underdogs, or are simply wondering how a community can dig itself out of a hole, look no further.
Like so many of us who have committed to proving to ourselves that we can get up off the mat, these comeback cities are determined to prove their supporters right and their naysayers wrong. They are so immensely confident in the spirit and resources of their city that its resurgence is inevitable. They're not hoping for a comeback, they're waiting.
 
The Book - New Grit: Startups in America's Comeback CitiesThe book is written in four parts....
Part 1 “Comeback Cities” introduces our cities, covers the reasons why anyone should care about these cities' resurgence and why startups are a key driver, while acknowledging the reasons cities like Kansas City, Columbus, and Nashville didn't quite make the cut.
Part 2 “Mechanical Traits: Industry, Institutions, and Expertise” contains examples from each of the comeback cities spanning historic industry expertise to cheaper costs of doing business to the importance of existing Fortune-500 companies in places like Cincinnati.
Part 3 “Cultural Traits: Love, Connection, and Realism” looks at the more human side of these cities. Think things like the intense love of place you've been exposed to by any Detroiter, Buffalonian, or Yinzer talking endlessly and lovingly about their hometown. This section also looks at the historic impact of only a few industries and employers on the entrepreneurial fabric of these cities' populations.
Finally, Part 4 “Igniting the Comeback” lays out the keys and steps to tapping into the traits shared by come back cities.

 
What I Need & What You'll Get This book will be published with New Degree Press. I set up the pre-order tiers to help cover the book's publishing costs. Money raised will go towards the following:
The editor I will work with to revise and publish my manuscript in December 2019
The cover design of my book - the mockups you see currently are a placeholder
The layout design for the interior of my book (physical copy and Ebook formats)
The copyediting for my book - to help polish things up prior to publication
The launch & promotion efforts for my book - when I ultimately publish this winter

When I pre-sell 100 copies of my book, I will publish. When I pre-sell 150 copies of my book, I will also publish an audiobook. When I pre-sell 200 copies of my book, I will publish a hardcover edition.

I am also offering some exclusive rewards for people who pre-order my book now:

You will receive a personally signed copy of my book when I publish
A personal, handwritten thank you note for pre-ordering my book
Your name will appear in a special acknowledgements section of my book
Early access to the introduction of my book and my entire manuscript, with the opportunity to review it and give me early feedback
The opportunity to help give me feedback and be involved in selecting my cover
I will do a book topic/workshop seminar where I will share experience the experiences of writing my book
And more...

story:
The Story

We had great jobs and promising Silicon Valley careers. A rent controlled apartment in one of the most expensive cities in the world. A newborn daughter. And yet we walked away from it all (not the newborn).

In September 2018, my husband, baby, and I left our lives behind to travel the world for a year to try to reconnect with what makes each of us happy. We traveled abroad for 303 days across 11 countries and 48 cities and towns, and spent more than a year in total bouncing from hotel room to guest room to B&B to Airbnb with little more than two suitcases and a travel crib. We returned to the US just in time to settle into the then-epicenter of a global pandemic, only to realize that the same lessons we learned while traveling where the ones that served us best while quarantining.

My name is Laura Weidman Powers and I am the author of Unstuck Together: Lessons in Parenting, Partnership, and Packing from 303 Days on the Road with a Baby. Unstuck Together is the story of three years of our lives: the year we decided to leave, the year we traveled abroad, and the year after we returned.

I wrote this book for the people in our lives and the people we met on our travels, the people who looked at our choices with longing, the people who looked at their lives and said “I could never...”, to show them that maybe, in fact, they could. I wrote this book for those who aren’t sure that they want starting a family to mean settling down. This book is for people who are responsible, predictable, reliable, and not spontaneous at all — because we get to have adventures, too.

Now that we’re all stuck navigating a global pandemic, this book has taken on new meaning. There is much that we learned about parenting and partnership while spending all our time together as a family during our year of travel that has informed how we have navigated the challenges of what will likely end up being a year or more of pandemic-induced isolation. And now that we and many of us are working completely remotely for the foreseeable future, it’s a chance to consider what it might be like to change the parts of our lives that aren’t serving us without also having to quit our jobs.

My hope is that, in reading this book, you will discover a new perspective on your own life and choices, that it will inspire you to think about where you are stuck -- and where it just feels that way. After all, with work, school, exercise, socializing, and more taking place online these days, getting creative with where and how we live and build community has never been more timely.

In this book, you'll also learn about things like:

  • How the experience of co-parenting across different cultures changed our notions of what is right for us;
  • What it's like to choose your destinations 4-5 days in advance based on your favorite foods or an obscure blog post you found; and
  • Which 12 items stayed with us through the entirety of our year of adventure.

You will love this book if you are feeling an acute sense of wanderlust — and want to do something about it.

Unstuck Together is a non-fiction book that speaks to those who are both ambitious and adventurous, those who have obligations and want new opportunities, and those who are looking at uprooting their lives and creating a new normal for their families for the first time.

 

The Book - Unstuck Together

The book is written in three parts.

Part 1: The choice to leave.
Part 1 tells the story of how I found myself successful but stuck, pregnant, and unhappy. You’ll hear the story of the girls weekend that changed my perspective and changed my life, and how my husband and I packed up everything — including our new daughter — to make a change.

Part 2: Our time on the road.
In Part 2, you’ll see us parenting across different cultures, adjusting our expectations and discovering where we hold firm. We learn how to spend tons of time together, and how important it is to spend a bit of time apart. We navigate work and leisure when lines are blurred, and try to tap into what brings each of us joy (spoiler alert: for the baby, it’s playgrounds).

Part 3: The return.
Part 3 recounts how we thought we were moving to New York to be closer to family and friends, culture and community and we ended up more isolated than ever as the city became the epicenter of the COVID-19 pandemic. We drew on every hard-won insight from our time abroad to navigate our time at home as everything we determined we wanted proves to be just out of reach.

 

What I Need & What You'll Get

This book will be published with New Degree Press. NDP is a hybrid publisher that takes care of everything required to publish a book (which is great because this is something I have no clue how to do) while I retain all the rights to the book (which is great because I wrote it). In this model instead of NDP covering the costs of publishing in exchange for owning the content, we work together to run a pre-sale campaign that covers the costs of publishing, and I retain ownership. Chance the Rapper would approve. The pre-order tiers I set up here help cover the costs for publishing my book. Money raised will go towards the following:
 
  • The Editor I will work with to revise and publish my manuscript in December 2020
  • The Cover Design of my book - the mockups you see currently are a placeholder!
  • The Layout Design for the interior of my book (physical copy, ebook formats)
  • The Copyediting for my book - to help polish the grammar and spelling prior to publication
  • The Launch & Promotion Efforts for my book - when I ultimately publish this holiday season
When I pre-sell 120 copies of my book, I will publish a paperback and e-book. When I pre-sell 150 copies of my book, I will also publish an audiobook. When I pre-sell 200 copies of my book, I will publish a hardcover edition.

I am also offering some exclusive rewards for people who pre-order my book now:
  • You will receive a personally signed copy of my book when I publish
  • You'll get a personal thank you note for pre-ordering my book
  • Your name will appear in a Special Acknowledgements section of my book
  • You'll get early access to the Introduction of my book, plus the opportunity to review portions of the manuscript and give me early feedback
  • You'll have the opportunity to review cover designs and help me select my cover
  • Access to a virtual talk-back where I will share more untold stories from our travels and more on the experience of writing the book
  • The chance to book your own private Unstuck Together event with me

 

Risks & Challenges

The biggest challenge with publishing a book is a) finishing the book, and b) delivering the finished book to the backer, specifically my mailing of the book to you.

My book is about 90% written as of today, which means that I’m close to getting it over the finish line (no doubt several of you backers will help with your feedback!). NDP will handle everything that it takes to turn my content into something that can sit on your coffee table (or bedside table, or bookshelf, or be viewed on your tablet — you get the picture).

And I have eliminated much of the shipping portion of the risk by building into each tier of the campaign the cost of shipping the signed copies to you (domestic). I will be working closely with New Degree Press to make sure we get the earliest possible ship date.

I will keep all pre-sale backers up to date as my book hits each key milestone! You will know when the copies of my book you pre-ordered are expected to ship as well as when the e-book is slated to be released.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help! You can...

  • Share my Pre-sale Campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, or LinkedIn with your friends, family, and network. Please use #unstucktogether and tag me (@laurawp on Twitter and @lewp on Instagram) so I can chime in to amplify your efforts.
  • You can easily share my Pre-Sale Campaign Page via Indiegogo at the top of the page.
  • Please consider sharing this campaign directly via email, text, or DM with 3-5 friends, family members, or co-workers who you think would enjoy my book.

Thank you so much of all of your love and support!

Thanks again,
Laura

story:
Milestones! 

Interview with Irish Philadelphia

 

Story of My Book

The Galvin Girls is a historical fiction novel based on the real lives of Helen Galvin and her four sisters, who immigrated from rural Ireland to Philadelphia in the 1920s. The story starts in early September 1929, just weeks before the Stock Market Crash that began the Great Depression. Bridie, the youngest of them, arrives at sixteen years old, expecting to live the same American Dream her sisters have seemed to achieve.

My name is Emily Schmidt and I am the author of The Galvin Girls. I wrote this book to preserve the immigrant experience of my great-grandmother, Helen Galvin, and her four sisters after visiting their rural hometown in western Ireland and seeing the very dock they stepped off to board their ships over to America. As a great-grandchild, I am part of the last generation to have known the last-surviving Galvin who immigrated to Philadelphia. And as the only writer in the family and a sister myself, I believe I can share this story best.

My hope is that, in reading this book, you will discover what it was like for young Irish immigrant women to make their own way at a pivotal time in American history. I want you to see this book as an opportunity to engage with themes of identity and independence, escape from the never-ending dismal news of the pandemic, and learn alongside the Galvin sisters about the importance of believing the best in others.

 

The Book Plot

When Bridie Galvin arrives to Philadelphia in September of 1929 at sixteen years old, she expects her four older sisters to welcome her with open arms and pockets full of money. Anna (24), Mary (22), Helen (21), and Theresa (17) had left rural Listowel, Ireland one by one to live on “Silver Street,” the idyllic road for those who achieved the American Dream. With an unexpected violent occurrence only moments after her arrival, Bridie quickly realizes that America is not what it seems. Anna struggles with protecting and providing for her family as the matriarch. Mary desires to start her own life independent of her sisters. Helen makes several short-sighted decisions that affect more than just herself. Theresa takes on a secret new job that brings unexpected trouble. Bridie tries to grow up faster than her sisters want. Together, they learn what it means to embrace America’s fast pace and bright lights but also stay true to their Irish homeland. Follow each sister through her journey of hardship, surprise, betrayal, and success as one of America’s darkest days gets closer.

You will love this book if you’re a sister, have sisters, or have a mother or grandmother with sisters. The relationship between sisters is one that transcends historical time period, race, religion, economic standing, social class — any barrier or label that separates people because it is a bond anyone can relate to. You will also enjoy this book if you’re an immigrant or the descendant of an immigrant, especially one from Ireland. Like sisterhood, all immigrant experiences share common threads and the Galvin sisters’ immigrant story is no different. Finally, you’ll love this book if you enjoy the historical fiction genre, specifically the 1920s period in America.

Ultimately, I hope that The Galvin Girls inspires reflection and fruitful dialogue, pressing into engaging questions like:

  • Who am I as a sister? Do I support my sister(s) or those who are/have sister(s) in the best way possible?
  • Why should we rely on our families, especially our sisters, in times of struggle? How much should we rely on them?
  • How can we better aid and empower immigrant communities in the United States, not only in crisis but every single day?

I really look forward to exploring these questions and beyond with my readers. Coming together and discussing family and crisis will change us all for the better.

 

What I Need & What You'll Get

This book will be published with New Degree Press. I set up the pre-order tiers to help cover the costs for publishing my book. Money raised will go towards the following:

  • The Editor I will work with to revise and publish my manuscript in December 2020
  • The Cover Design of my book - the mock-ups you see currently are a placeholder!
  • The Layout Design for the interior of my book (Physical Copy, Ebook Formats)
  • The Copyediting for my book - to make help polish the grammar and spelling prior to publication
  • The Launch & Promotion Efforts for my book - when I ultimately publish this winter

 

When I pre-sell 120 copies of my book, I will publish.

I am also offering some exclusive rewards for people who preorder my book now:

  • A personally signed copy of my book when I publish
  • A personal, handwritten thank you note for preordering my book
  • Your name will appear in a Special Acknowledgements section of my book
  • Early access to the Introduction of my book and some additional sections of my manuscript, with the opportunity to review it and give me early feedback as a beta reader
  • The opportunity to help give me feedback and be involved in selecting my cover
  • An invitation to my launch party
  • A book topic/workshop seminar where I will share the experiences of writing my book
  • And more...

 

About the Author

Emily Schmidt is a recent Stanford University graduate and will be pursuing a master’s degree at Arizona State University’s Walter Cronkite School of Journalism and Mass Communication this coming autumn. She grew up celebrating her maternal Irish roots as a competitive Irish dancer with Rince Ri School of Irish Dance, even participating in the Philadelphia St. Patrick’s Day parade every March. Tracing her great-grandmother’s family back generations in Ireland on Ancestry.com during high school only intensified her love for the culture and desire to someday share her family’s story with the world.

While at Stanford, Emily took “Twentieth Century Irish Literature” with renowned Irish poet Eavan Boland, where she discovered her love for James Joyce’s Dubliners. The beginning threads of The Galvin Girls appeared in short stories Emily wrote for her subsequent creative writing classes. In the summers following her sophomore and junior years, she traveled to Ireland with her family to explore the places where her great-grandmother lived and meet with the daughter of the youngest Galvin sister, Josephine, who decided to stay in Ireland. It wasn’t until she sat down with Dr. Adam Johnson, her Pulitzer Prize-winning professor for “Advanced Fiction Writing,” that she pieced together the basic plot of The Galvin Girls.

When she’s not writing, Emily can be found crocheting anything and everything, taking an absurd number of Buzzfeed quizzes, or re-watching Downtown Abbey for the fifth time.

For more information you can connect with Emily at emilyschmidt@emilyschmidtauthor.com  and find her on LinkedIn, Facebook, and Instagram.

 

Questions You May Have 

Q: Why did I choose New Degree Press?
A: If you’re unfamiliar with the publishing world, I can assure you it’s extremely difficult to break into as a young, unpublished writer. Traditional publishing has a very high rejection rate and one can spend years submitting manuscripts without any acceptances or even feedback. Self-publishing is a route that requires one to wear every hat—writer, editor, marketer, etc. It can also cost a lot of money to hire editors to ensure one’s work is up to publishing standards. I wanted to take a path down the middle with hybrid publishing, where I receive the industry expertise and structure to write the best possible book and also keep my own copyright. (Think of Jo from Greta Gerwig’s adaptation of Little Women.)

Q: How much of the book is fiction?
A: The main characters of the book—the Galvin sisters and their love interests—were my real relatives. I based their personalities on stories I’ve heard from people who knew them. All minor characters are purely made up. Many of the places exist or once existed in Philadelphia: Broad Street Station, Wanamaker’s, Apex Hosiery, St. Columba’s, North Bonsall Street. All major historical events occurred and were highly researched to ensure an accurate depiction. Some of the events that occur to the Galvin sisters are real, but many are completely fictional or altered to fit the timeline of the plot.

Q: Why didn’t I write a biography?
A: I didn’t have enough information. The children of the Galvin sisters are now in their eighties, and several of them passed away before I even conceived the idea of writing the novel. Mary’s daughter, Caye, died my junior year and Helen’s son, my grandfather, passed last October. And even then, they had a limited number of stories to share because they’re older and don’t remember everything. I have historical records from Ancestry.com, albums of old photographs, and my own experience visiting where they grew up in Ireland, but beyond that, there’s not enough information to write a biography.

Q: What would the real Galvin sisters think of this book?
A: When I interviewed Mary’s daughter, Caye, she told me that the Galvin sisters deserved to be known. She always thought someone would write a book about them. For whatever reason, the universe has dropped that task in my lap and I’m doing my absolute best to honor authentically through my art. I believe they would smile, laugh, and want to share it with others. And in the words of my great-grandmother Helen, she’d say, “Ooooo Em-ly.”

Q: Am I going to write more books in the future?
A: Absolutely! I hope publishing The Galvin Girls will give me the experience and credibility to get my own literary agent. Writing a novel the second time around should (hopefully!) be much easier than the first. I do have some ideas in the back of my brain pleading to be explored, but for now, revising and editing The Galvin Girls is my primary task until at least mid-October.

Q: How can I be going to journalism school and writing a novel? Don’t they conflict with one another?
A: The beauty about being a writer is that I don’t need to define myself one way or another. I’ve written poetry, short stories, articles, personal essays, and now a novel. I might end up working for a newspaper or magazine, but that doesn’t take away from my imagination. I’m just practicing and perfecting different sets of writing skills. Kurt Vonnegut was a journalist for Sports Illustrated at one point!

 

Risks & Challenges

The biggest challenge with publishing a book is delivering the finished book to the backer, specifically my mailing of the book to you. I have eliminated this risk by building into the campaign the mailing and shipping costs of your signed copies to you within each pre-order tier.

The risk of delivering the pre-sale copies of my book is contingent on the publisher we use. I will be working closely with New Degree Press to make sure we get the earliest possible ship date of the signed book copy to you. We will keep all pre-sale backers up-to-date as my book hits each key milestone and publishes. You will know when the copies of my book you pre-ordered are expected to ship.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Please share my pre-sale campaign on Facebook, Twitter, and LinkedIn with your friends, family and network. Please use #TheGalvinGirls and tag me as well as my publisher, New Degree Press, so we can help amplify your efforts.
  • You can easily share my pre-sale campaign page via Indiegogo at the top of the page.
  • Please share my book to 5 friends, family members, or co-workers who you think would enjoy it. Please do this as a text message or direct message on social media.

Thank you so much for all of your love and support!

Sláinte!
Emily
story_txt:
Milestones! Interview with Irish Philadelphia Story of My BookThe Galvin Girls is a historical fiction novel based on the real lives of Helen Galvin and her four sisters, who immigrated from rural Ireland to Philadelphia in the 1920s. The story starts in early September 1929, just weeks before the Stock Market Crash that began the Great Depression. Bridie, the youngest of them, arrives at sixteen years old, expecting to live the same American Dream her sisters have seemed to achieve.My name is Emily Schmidt and I am the author of The Galvin Girls. I wrote this book to preserve the immigrant experience of my great-grandmother, Helen Galvin, and her four sisters after visiting their rural hometown in western Ireland and seeing the very dock they stepped off to board their ships over to America. As a great-grandchild, I am part of the last generation to have known the last-surviving Galvin who immigrated to Philadelphia. And as the only writer in the family and a sister myself, I believe I can share this story best.My hope is that, in reading this book, you will discover what it was like for young Irish immigrant women to make their own way at a pivotal time in American history. I want you to see this book as an opportunity to engage with themes of identity and independence, escape from the never-ending dismal news of the pandemic, and learn alongside the Galvin sisters about the importance of believing the best in others. The Book PlotWhen Bridie Galvin arrives to Philadelphia in September of 1929 at sixteen years old, she expects her four older sisters to welcome her with open arms and pockets full of money. Anna (24), Mary (22), Helen (21), and Theresa (17) had left rural Listowel, Ireland one by one to live on “Silver Street,” the idyllic road for those who achieved the American Dream. With an unexpected violent occurrence only moments after her arrival, Bridie quickly realizes that America is not what it seems. Anna struggles with protecting and providing for her family as the matriarch. Mary desires to start her own life independent of her sisters. Helen makes several short-sighted decisions that affect more than just herself. Theresa takes on a secret new job that brings unexpected trouble. Bridie tries to grow up faster than her sisters want. Together, they learn what it means to embrace America’s fast pace and bright lights but also stay true to their Irish homeland. Follow each sister through her journey of hardship, surprise, betrayal, and success as one of America’s darkest days gets closer.You will love this book if you’re a sister, have sisters, or have a mother or grandmother with sisters. The relationship between sisters is one that transcends historical time period, race, religion, economic standing, social class — any barrier or label that separates people because it is a bond anyone can relate to. You will also enjoy this book if you’re an immigrant or the descendant of an immigrant, especially one from Ireland. Like sisterhood, all immigrant experiences share common threads and the Galvin sisters’ immigrant story is no different. Finally, you’ll love this book if you enjoy the historical fiction genre, specifically the 1920s period in America.Ultimately, I hope that The Galvin Girls inspires reflection and fruitful dialogue, pressing into engaging questions like:
Who am I as a sister? Do I support my sister(s) or those who are/have sister(s) in the best way possible?
Why should we rely on our families, especially our sisters, in times of struggle? How much should we rely on them?
How can we better aid and empower immigrant communities in the United States, not only in crisis but every single day?
I really look forward to exploring these questions and beyond with my readers. Coming together and discussing family and crisis will change us all for the better. What I Need & What You'll GetThis book will be published with New Degree Press. I set up the pre-order tiers to help cover the costs for publishing my book. Money raised will go towards the following:
The Editor I will work with to revise and publish my manuscript in December 2020
The Cover Design of my book - the mock-ups you see currently are a placeholder!
The Layout Design for the interior of my book (Physical Copy, Ebook Formats)
The Copyediting for my book - to make help polish the grammar and spelling prior to publication
The Launch & Promotion Efforts for my book - when I ultimately publish this winter
 When I pre-sell 120 copies of my book, I will publish.I am also offering some exclusive rewards for people who preorder my book now:
A personally signed copy of my book when I publish
A personal, handwritten thank you note for preordering my book
Your name will appear in a Special Acknowledgements section of my book
Early access to the Introduction of my book and some additional sections of my manuscript, with the opportunity to review it and give me early feedback as a beta reader
The opportunity to help give me feedback and be involved in selecting my cover
An invitation to my launch party
A book topic/workshop seminar where I will share the experiences of writing my book
And more...
 About the AuthorEmily Schmidt is a recent Stanford University graduate and will be pursuing a master’s degree at Arizona State University’s Walter Cronkite School of Journalism and Mass Communication this coming autumn. She grew up celebrating her maternal Irish roots as a competitive Irish dancer with Rince Ri School of Irish Dance, even participating in the Philadelphia St. Patrick’s Day parade every March. Tracing her great-grandmother’s family back generations in Ireland on Ancestry.com during high school only intensified her love for the culture and desire to someday share her family’s story with the world.While at Stanford, Emily took “Twentieth Century Irish Literature” with renowned Irish poet Eavan Boland, where she discovered her love for James Joyce’s Dubliners. The beginning threads of The Galvin Girls appeared in short stories Emily wrote for her subsequent creative writing classes. In the summers following her sophomore and junior years, she traveled to Ireland with her family to explore the places where her great-grandmother lived and meet with the daughter of the youngest Galvin sister, Josephine, who decided to stay in Ireland. It wasn’t until she sat down with Dr. Adam Johnson, her Pulitzer Prize-winning professor for “Advanced Fiction Writing,” that she pieced together the basic plot of The Galvin Girls.When she’s not writing, Emily can be found crocheting anything and everything, taking an absurd number of Buzzfeed quizzes, or re-watching Downtown Abbey for the fifth time.For more information you can connect with Emily at emilyschmidt@emilyschmidtauthor.com  and find her on LinkedIn, Facebook, and Instagram. Questions You May Have Q: Why did I choose New Degree Press?A: If you’re unfamiliar with the publishing world, I can assure you it’s extremely difficult to break into as a young, unpublished writer. Traditional publishing has a very high rejection rate and one can spend years submitting manuscripts without any acceptances or even feedback. Self-publishing is a route that requires one to wear every hat—writer, editor, marketer, etc. It can also cost a lot of money to hire editors to ensure one’s work is up to publishing standards. I wanted to take a path down the middle with hybrid publishing, where I receive the industry expertise and structure to write the best possible book and also keep my own copyright. (Think of Jo from Greta Gerwig’s adaptation of Little Women.)Q: How much of the book is fiction?A: The main characters of the book—the Galvin sisters and their love interests—were my real relatives. I based their personalities on stories I’ve heard from people who knew them. All minor characters are purely made up. All major historical events occurred and were highly researched to ensure an accurate depiction. Some of the events that occur to the Galvin sisters are real, but many are completely fictional or altered to fit the timeline of the plot.Q: Why didn’t I write a biography?A: I didn’t have enough information. The children of the Galvin sisters are now in their eighties, and several of them passed away before I even conceived the idea of writing the novel. Mary’s daughter, Caye, died my junior year and Helen’s son, my grandfather, passed last October. And even then, they had a limited number of stories to share because they’re older and don’t remember everything. I have historical records from Ancestry.com, albums of old photographs, and my own experience visiting where they grew up in Ireland, but beyond that, there’s not enough information to write a biography.Q: What would the real Galvin sisters think of this book?A: When I interviewed Mary’s daughter, Caye, she told me that the Galvin sisters deserved to be known. She always thought someone would write a book about them. For whatever reason, the universe has dropped that task in my lap and I’m doing my absolute best to honor authentically through my art. I believe they would smile, laugh, and want to share it with others. And in the words of my great-grandmother Helen, she’d say, “Ooooo Em-ly.”Q: Am I going to write more books in the future?A: Absolutely! I hope publishing The Galvin Girls will give me the experience and credibility to get my own literary agent. Writing a novel the second time around should (hopefully!) be much easier than the first. I do have some ideas in the back of my brain pleading to be explored, but for now, revising and editing The Galvin Girls is my primary task until at least mid-October.Q: How can I be going to journalism school and writing a novel? Don’t they conflict with one another?A: The beauty about being a writer is that I don’t need to define myself one way or another.
